posts.cooked:
Apple has recently introduced a feature called Lockdown Mode for iOS that disables certain features (in Safari and iMessage for example) to dramatically decrease attack surface. Apple has finally realised that there are users that are at risk to a degree where this is highly beneficial to them. It would be great if Signal would offer opt-in toggles in the iOS and Android apps to decrease the attack surface dramatically. Things like disabling WebRTC and maybe even a text-only mode. Similar to Lockdown Mode, a disclaimer could be made that doing this is not recommended unless someone is at risk of being targeted by extremely sophisticated attacks.

People that might be the target of these kinds of attacks are often using Signal to protect themselves. They should not have to worry about their chat history or potentially their entire phone being compromised through the Signal app

posts.cooked: Signal is secure by default.

The iOS lockdown mode is a special setting, which applies to the OS, as well as to Apple Services (FaceTime or iMessage), to websites and also to third-party apps. My understanding is, that third-party apps can participate in iOS lockdown mode, if they wish to do so.
What does the lockdown mode do with third-party apps?
Since I use iOS, have lockdown mode activated, I can just report my own experiences.
In lockdown mode, fonts are limited. In websites (when using Safari), as well as with apps, for which lockdown mode has been activated, you have just a very small set of fonts available. So websites look sometimes a bit ugly, simpler, and less structured.
Obviously, Apple seems to believe, that a wider range of fonts increases the attack surface.
So using Apple lockdown mode, Signal would look ‚Äúugly‚Äù.

Then, all kind of graphical elements are replaced. Take a chess app, where you have buttons under the chess board, for moving forward or backward. These buttons are, in general, graphical elements (‚Äúpictures‚Äù), which are being loaded from somewhere. All these pictures are replaced, either by very simple symbols, or letters - both included in the standard fonts, being used in lockdown mode.
Apple seems to believe, that all kind of pictures, which are there for the optical improvement of the GUI, increase the attack surface, since these graphical elements could be manipulated.
This is sometimes hard to handle, because if a button for forward and backward are replaced by ‚Äúu‚Äù and ‚ÄúB‚Äù, you don‚Äôt know, what it means.

in iMessage, Apple lockdown mode also restricts the documents, which can be sent. You can send someone simple pictures (jpg), but no .zip or pdf or anything else. Here, Apple seems to believe, that some other formats than jpg are extremly dangerous and hard to handle, security-wise.

Only Signal team can say, if all this would make any sense for the iOS version of Signal.

Well, I can see where you‚Äôre coming from with this idea, although I don‚Äôt really know what features Signal could disable and whether they actually should do it. The point is: we know about a couple iMessage exploits, with the most sophisticated being of course ForcedEntry, we know about at least one WhatsApp vulnerability that was exploited in the wild. But we have no evidence that was ever the case with Signal.

How does Lockdown Mode work?

  • it blocks attachments other that photos, videos and audio messages (which, if we get to that level of protections (and paranoia ), also could be maliciously exploited at some point; unless Apple has rewritten those parts of the OS in Swift (or other memory-safe language)) | What could Signal do here? Nothing really. Because there‚Äôs no way Signal‚Äôs server could enforce no attachments policy, as it doesn‚Äôt know the content of a message‚Ä¶ And any client-side locks wouldn‚Äôt help, because if my payload, ahem, message has arrived on your phone, it‚Äôs game over.
  • incoming FaceTime calls are blocked unless you have previously called that person or contact | In Signal‚Äôs case you cannot call someone that hasn‚Äôt accepted your message request. In short, just don‚Äôt call or message someone you suspect could infect you with Pegasus
  • most importantly they ‚Äúharden‚Äù Safari/WebKit by disabling just-in-time compilation for JavaScript, WebRTC, third party fonts, among other things since most vulnerabilities have this magic sentence in their CVE description ‚ÄúProcessing maliciously crafted web content may lead to arbitrary code execution.‚Äù

To sum it all up: out of Chromium vulnerabilities 70% are memory safety related. That‚Äôs why it‚Äôs important we migrate to languages that provide (more or absolute) memory safety, like Swift, Kotlin and Rust (). And that‚Äôs exactly what Signal is doing.

PS. I hope C and C++ can die sooner than I do!

posts.cooked:
So as I said, don‚Äôt accept message requests and don‚Äôt call people you don‚Äôt trust. And if you‚Äôre aiming for that level of security, I‚Äôm sure you‚Äôre using a firewall, or at least a custom DNS, so you might as well block Signal‚Äôs calling related URLs and there‚Äôs no way any calls would be even set up.

Saying that ‚ÄúWebRTC is C++ and will remain as such‚Äù is like saying that no software was ever rewritten or abandoned for a better alternative. Google is one the most security-conscious companies and they‚Äôre actively investigating Rust-C++ interoperability (mainly for Chromium use). Also, you don‚Äôt have to rewrite everything, just the most vulnerable components. For instance they experimented with Swift JSON parser.

DNS and Firewall does not help with this. Blocking URLS‚Äôs (highly doubt you could even make that work) is not reasonable for people with high threat models that are also not technical. Also only allowing calls and messages from people you don‚Äôt trust (which in itself is not available) only moves the goalpost a bit. An attacker can attack the device of a known contact first and then exploit yours with that device.

I‚Äôm not saying that WebRTC or certain parsers in Signal are a bad thing. It is a great thing because it allows for end to end encrypted calls and file exchanges for everyone. All I‚Äôm saying is that there is a small minority of users that has to worry about these kinds of attacks, and there should be one or more toggles in the app to give these people the option to greatly reduce the attack surface. Companies moving adopting more Rust or Swift gradually (which is a great thing don‚Äôt get me wrong) is irrelevant here

You seem mainly concerned about WebRTC, but iOS Lockdown Mode does not disable FaceTime calls, so you are proposing something even more restrictive.

I said that if you desperately want to disallow calls, there‚Äôs a workaround, because there is simply 0% chance Signal implements such a toggle.

You doubt that I can do what? Block URLs used for call establishment?

And moving to memory safe languages is not irrelevant! It‚Äôs the key problem here and I even provided a source for that! Most of those RCEs are possible, because of stupid unsafe C/C++ that allow for use after-frees, integer overflows, etc.

Apple made some choices, I made some arguments, but you can have your own strong opinions and feature requests. People concentrate too much on million dollars hacks, but forget about the basics.
Most common exploits are those that affect an interface between chair and a keyboard.
Thank you, that‚Äôs all from me.
And guess what? We‚Äôre going to see infections despite Lockdown Mode.
